conclusion: Analyze the motion of the particle as it passes through the electric field and then enters the magnetic field.
The particle moves in a straight line under the influence of an electric field inside the plates.
Since the particle is negatively charged, it will experience a force in the direction opposite to the electric field.
The electric force must have canceled out the initial component of the velocity parallel to the plates.
The particle's velocity after passing through the electric field is purely perpendicular to the plates.
When the particle exits the electric field and enters the magnetic field, it experiences a centripetal force due to the Lorentz force.
The radius \( R \) of the circular path can be determined using the formula \( R =  rac{mv}{qB} \).

Given that the particle just fails to exit the magnetic field from side \( cd \), the radius \( R \) should be equal to the distance from the center of the circular path to the edge of the square region \( abcd \).
Since the side length of the square is \( 2L \), the distance from the center to the edge is \( L \). Therefore, the radius \( R \) must be equal to \( L \).
Substituting \( R = L \) into the formula for the radius of curvature gives \( L =  rac{mv}{qB} \).
Solving for \( v \) gives \( v =  rac{qBL}{m} \).
The magnitude of the velocity of the particle when it is shot into point \( S \) is \(  oxed{ rac{qBL}{m}} \).
